string-array.name: abbreviation_list_child
string-array.item: Application Programming Interface: \n\n a set of protocols and tools used for building software applications
Advanced Encryption Standard: \n\n a widely used symmetric encryption algorithm
American Standard Code for Information Interchange: \n\n a character encoding standard for electronic communication
Basic Input/Output System: \n\n a firmware interface that initializes and tests hardware components during the boot process
Central Processing Unit: \n\n the primary component of a computer that performs most of the processing
Cascading Style Sheets: \n\n a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML
Database Management System: \n\n software for managing and organizing data in databases
Domain Name System: \n\n a system that translates domain names into IP addresses
File Transfer Protocol: \n\n a protocol used for transferring files over the internet
Graphical User Interface: \n\n a type of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical elements
Hypertext Markup Language: \n\n a markup language used for creating web pages and other information that can be displayed in a web browser
Hypertext Transfer Protocol: \n\n a protocol used for transmitting data over the internet
Internet Protocol: \n\n a protocol used for communicating data across a network of computers
Internet Service Provider: \n\n a company that provides internet access to customers
Local Area Network: \n\n a network that connects computers and devices in a limited geographical area such as a home, office, or building.
Wide Area Network: \n\n a network that spans over a large geographical area and connects computers and devices across different locations.
Internet Service Provider: \n\n a company that provides internet access to customers.
Domain Name System: \n\n a system that translates domain names (e.g., www.example.com) into IP addresses.
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol: \n\n a protocol used for sending and receiving email messages.
File Transfer Protocol: \n\n a protocol used for transferring files between computers over a network.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol: \n\n a protocol used for transmitting data over the internet, especially web pages.
Hypertext Markup Language: \n\n a markup language used for creating web pages and other documents that can be displayed in a web browser.
Cascading Style Sheets: \n\n a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML.
Extensible Markup Language: \n\n a markup language used for storing and transporting data.
Access Control List: \n\n A list of permissions attached to an object in computing that specifies which users or system processes are allowed to access the object.
Application Programming Interface: \n\n A set of protocols and tools for building software applications. An API specifies how software components should interact.
Business Intelligence: \n\n A set of techniques and tools for analyzing data to help make informed business decisions.
Customer Relationship Management: \n\n A strategy for managing a companys interactions with customers, clients, and sales prospects.
Enterprise Resource Planning: \n\n A software system that manages a companys resources, including financials, manufacturing, human resources, and supply chain.
Graphics Processing Unit: \n\n A specialized processor designed to handle the intensive computations required for rendering graphics and video.
Integrated Development Environment: \n\n A software application that provides comprehensive facilities for software development, including editing, debugging, and building.
Internet of Things: \n\n The interconnection via the Internet of computing devices embedded in everyday objects, enabling them to send and receive data.
JavaScript Object Notation: \n\n A lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write, and easy for machines to parse and generate.
Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions: \n\n A standard for encoding multimedia attachments, such as images and audio, in email messages.
Natural Language Processing: \n\n A field of computer science and artificial intelligence concerned with the interactions between computers and human (natural) languages.
Optical Character Recognition: \n\n The electronic conversion of images of typed, handwritten, or printed text into machine-encoded text.
Operating System: \n\n The software that manages computer hardware resources and provides common services for computer programs.
Random Access Memory: \n\n A form of computer data storage that allows data to be read or written in almost the same amount of time regardless of the physical location of data inside the memory.
Read-Only Memory: \n\n A type of computer memory that can only be read and not written to, used mainly to store firmware.
Really Simple Syndication: \n\n A web feed format used to publish frequently updated works such as blog entries, news headlines, and podcasts.
